title: 115_hr2357
content: The Act is titled the "United States Employee Ownership Bank Act" and includes findings. Congress finds that the manufacturing sector lost 4,929,000 jobs between January 2000 and January 2017, with only 12,355,000 workers employed in the sector as of January 2017. The United States had a trade deficit of $502,300,000,000 at the end of 2016, including a $347,037,900,000 deficit with China. Preserving and increasing decent paying jobs is a top priority, and establishing the United States Employee Ownership Bank to support Employee Stock Ownership Plans will help achieve this goal. The United States aims to preserve and increase decent paying jobs by supporting Employee Stock Ownership Plans and worker-owned cooperatives. The Act defines key terms such as "Bank," "eligible worker-owned cooperative," "employee stock ownership plan," and "Secretary." It establishes the United States Employee Ownership Bank within the Department of the Treasury. Before the end of the 90-day period from enactment, the Secretary will establish the United States Employee Ownership Bank to promote employee ownership and participation in company decision-making. The Director appointed by the Secretary will manage the Bank and hire necessary staff. The Bank is authorized to provide direct loans. The United States Employee Ownership Bank is authorized to provide direct loans and loan guarantees to facilitate employee ownership in companies, including purchasing, increasing, or expanding employee ownership levels to preserve employment. The Employee Ownership Bank requires a business plan showing at least 51% ownership by an employee stock ownership plan or worker-owned cooperative, with a board elected based on a 1 share to 1 vote basis. The Employee Ownership Bank requires voting according to section 409(e) of the Internal Revenue Code, employees to receive company progress information, and a feasibility study from a third party to ensure financial viability. The Employee Ownership Bank requires voting according to section 409(e) of the Internal Revenue Code, employees to receive company progress information, and a feasibility study from a third party to ensure financial viability. Loans or loan guarantees provided under this section must bear interest at a rate determined by the Secretary and have a term not exceeding 12 years. SEC. 5. EMPLOYEE RIGHT OF FIRST REFUSAL BEFORE PLANT OR FACILITY CLOSING. Section 3 of the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification Act is amended to include provisions for Employee Stock Ownership Plans and Eligible Worker-Owned Cooperatives in the event of a plant or facility closing. The Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification Act is amended to include provisions for Employee Stock Ownership Plans and Eligible Worker-Owned Cooperatives in the event of a plant or facility closing. The value of the company subject to the plan or cooperative shall be determined by an independent third party appraisal, shared evenly between the employer and employees. Exemptions apply if the employer retains assets for business continuation within the US or intends to continue the business after a plant closing. The Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification Act is amended to include provisions for Employee Stock Ownership Plans and Eligible Worker-Owned Cooperatives in the event of a plant or facility closing, with exemptions if the employer intends to continue the business at another plant within the United States. SEC. 6. REGULATIONS ON SAFETY AND SOUNDNESS AND PREVENTING COMPETITION WITH COMMERCIAL INSTITUTIONS. The Secretary must prescribe regulations within 90 days to ensure the safety of the Bank and prevent competition with commercial financial institutions. SEC. 7. COMMUNITY REINVESTMENT CREDIT. SEC. 7. COMMUNITY REINVESTMENT CREDIT. This section amends the Community Reinvestment Act to allow financial institutions to support employee stock ownership plans and worker-owned cooperatives. Authorization of appropriations for the Secretary to carry out the Act includes $500,000,000 for fiscal year 2018 and necessary sums for subsequent years.
